awd_titl_txt: RUI: Experimental Study of Dipolar Solid Helium
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Description:
With its two protons and two neutrons, helium-4 is one of the simplest atoms next to hydrogen. However, although apparently simple, helium has very complex behavior at low temperatures due quantum mechanical effects. One type of these effects is that helium will not freeze under normal pressures, but rather will remain a liquid all the way down to absolute zero (T = 0 K). In order to get helium to freeze, it must be squeezed to over 25 times atmospheric pressure, essentially forcing the atoms into a solid. Another consequence of the quantum nature of helium is the possibility that this strange solid can display superfluid properties (i.e. flow without friction). This is an idea that, although very strange, is predicted to occur under the right conditions, but experiments have had mixed results in detecting such a phase. This project studies the electronic properties of helium and exploits these properties to develop a new route to creating solid helium. This new method of growing solid helium crystals gives researchers a certain amount of control over system parameters that have been typically inaccessible to other solid helium experiments. The research also studies quantum effects in solid helium grown using this new method, with the goal of observing superfluidity in solid helium. Finally, this project engages undergraduate students in low temperature physics experiments at California State University, Sacramento (Sacramento State), which is primarily an undergraduate institution serving a large, ethnically diverse student body. Through this research, under-represented minority students, develop a range of highly technical skills, helping to bring diversity to the STEM workforce.

Technical Description:
Superfluid properties have so far been conclusively observed in liquids and gasses. This begs the question: can superfluid properties exist in solids as well? This question has captivated low temperature physicists for over 50 years. Due to its quantum nature, it is believed that solid helium has the best chance of displaying superfluid behavior, although experimental searches have been met with varying success. This project brings a new perspective to solid helium research by studying electronic properties of solid helium in order to develop a new method of creating solid helium. Specifically, an external electric field is used to control the dipole-dipole interactions that are the basis of inter-atomic interactions between neutral helium atoms. Given the right conditions, these dipolar interactions cause the atoms to form a lattice, creating "dipolar solid helium". With this method, the low temperature research team at California State University, Sacramento, studies the differences in the behavior of a classically-behaved solid and a quantum solid leading to the possibility of observing superfluid behavior in the solid, or a, "supersolid" phase. Specific goals of this project are to: 1) observe the formation and behavior of dipolar solid helium under varying interaction strengths; 2) measure the electronic properties of both conventional and dipolar solid helium; and 3) build a low temperature cryostat that is conducive to undergraduate research. These experiments build a framework for a large range of future experiments that will study the behavior of a dipolar quantum solid. Such experiments offer insights into the behavior of materials that are important as technologies get smaller, and approach the limit where quantum effects become important.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of this project was to explore new routes to studying quantum solids. The central idea was to develop a new method of creating solid helium samples that provided more control over the interaction strength between the atoms. To do this, the project was divided into three parts:

  1. Complete construction of the low temperature system.
  2. Work with scientists at a nano-fabrication facility to design and build the apparatus for the solid helium experiment.
  3. Perform the experiments and disseminate the results.

Of these goals the first two were completed, but we have run into delays, both from the COVID-19 pandemic, and problems with instruments at the nanofabrication facility, that have so far prevented us from completing the last goal. Thus, even though the award term has ended, the project is not completed. However, we have built the low temperature system to be able to work on limited resources, and thus expect work on this project to continue.

The main outcome from this project so far is the completion of the low-temperature system. This system has been built in a way to be robust and flexible, and to allow undergraduate students to be able to run it. In fact, several students have already been trained to use it, and are able to perform their own experiments with it. This ties into one of the central goals of the lab, which is to give undergraduate students experience in designing and running scientific experiments.

With the low temperature system working, some of the student projects that have taken place have led to a new set of experiments to study the low temperature properties of 3D printed materials. This includes the thermal conductivity, thermal contraction and permeability of polylactic acid, which is a common material for use in 3D printed material. The goal here is to determine if and where these materials can be used for cryostat construction. Results of this experiment have been presented at both local and national conferences.

One of the biggest impacts of this project was that it provided opportunities for undergraduate students to get experience in a large range of highly technical experimental skills. Students working in the laboratory had to learn how to design and build components for their experiments, how to make their respective measurements at low temperatures, and how to use the instrumentation to perform the measurement. These are valuable skills both for students going on to graduate school and those looking for jobs in industry. Alumni from the lab have gone on to graduate programs at MIT, Texas Christian University, USC, UCLA, UC Davis UC Santa Cruz to name a few, and have also gone on to work at many companies both locally and around the nation.

Additionally, Sacramento State serves a very diverse region, and has been named a Hispanic Serving Institution (HSI) and an Asian American and Native American Pacific Islander Serving Institution (AANSPISI). Accordingly, the students working in the lab are also diverse. During the life of this award, I supervised 14 students in the lab, and about half of them were from groups that are underrepresented in physics. Thus, another important impact of this project was in giving students from underrepresented groups research experience as undergraduate students and contributing to the goal of the broader physics community to increase diversity in the field.

Given what we have been able to accomplish in the laboratory due to this award, I am excited for the lab’s future. The funding from this award has so far allowed us to build the framework for a robust, and productive low temperature physics laboratory. I suspect that we will have continued success in the goal of beginning the training of a new crop of diverse scientists while contributing to the scientific knowledge of the low temperature community.

Modified by: Michael W Ray
